page.title: 04Sandringham Church
page.content:
The church of St. Mary Magdalene was first built in the 14th. century, rebuilt in the 16th. century and extensively restored in the latter part of the 19th. century. It stands hidden in the woodland to the West of Sandringham House.
Visitors are immediately aware that this is a Royal Church. They are amazed by the silver altar-piece and pulpit, appreciative of the beautiful silver processional cross, and charmed by the delightful statue of St. George slaying the Dragon which stands guard over the Royal Pew.
Despite its appeal to the tourist, it remains the spiritual centre of the Sandringham Group of Parishes, and it maintains a pleasingly large Sunday congregation.
